review.title: Generalized Biwords for Bitext Compression and Translation Spotting
review.abstract: Large bilingual parallel texts (also known as bitexts) are usually stored in a compressed form, and previous work has shown that they can be more efficiently compressed if the fact that the two texts are mutual translations is exploited. For example, a bitext can be seen as a sequence of biwords ---pairs of parallel words with a high probability of co-occurrence--- that can be used as an intermediate representation in the compression process. However, the simple biword approach described in the literature can only exploit one-to-one word alignments and cannot tackle the reordering of words. We therefore introduce a generalization of biwords which can describe multi-word expressions and reorderings. We also describe some methods for the binary compression of generalized biword sequences, and compare their performance when different schemes are applied to the extraction of the biword sequence. In addition, we show that this generalization of biwords allows for the implementation of an efficient algorithm to look on the compressed bitext for words or text segments in one of the texts and retrieve their counterpart translations in the other text ---an application usually referred to as translation spotting--- with only some minor modifications in the compression algorithm.

Word aligners usually work by matching which pairs of sentences are parallel in the bittext, i.e. a plausible reciprocal sequence translation exists. Sentence algorithms are often based on simple statistical models for the correlation between sentence lengths (Brown, Lai, & Mercer, 1991; Gale & Church, 1993). Current word aligners use word-based statistical translation models (Brown, Pietra, Jelinek, Lafferty, & Roossin, 1990; Brown, Pietra, Pietra, & Mercer, 1993) to calculate the most probable alignment in the two sentences.

sections.heading: 3. Compression of Biword Sequences
sections.text: It is clearly possible to compress the intermediate representation introduced in the previous section by applying a wide range of approaches. Here, we describe and evaluate two different encoding methods, namely Tre (paragraph 3.2) and 2lcab (paragraph 3.3), which use a word-based implementation of Huffman encoding (Moffat & Turpin, 1997; Turpin & Moffat, 2000), in which the input strings are mapped to integers and then compressed with Huffman codewords (Huffman, 1952). Both methods encode the offsets as described below (paragraph 3.1), but differ in the way they encode the lexical components of the biword sequence. Using Huffman codewords allows the two methods described here great spatial savings, but makes it inefficient to search for words in the compressed bittext and find the sequences in the left sequence.

sections.heading: 3.1 Structural Encoding
sections.text: Initial tests showed that the biword extraction algorithm was able to generate sequences with a high number (usually over 70%) of biwords without displacements, and therefore an array of zero values can be considered a standard offset sequence. Thus, the offsets can be encoded as two streams of integer values: • The positions P = (p1, p2,.., pN) of the biwords with shifts in sequence B. These positions can be expressed in relation to the previous biword with shifts in B; for example, the biwords with shifts in Figure 3 are P = (1, 5, 2). • The offset values O for the biwords with shifts. For example, the offsets are O = (0, 1, 1, 2); the first two offsets belong to the first biword with shifts, while the following two belong to the second and third biwords with shifts.

sections.heading: 3.2 The TRE Compressor
sections.text: The translation relationship-based encoder (Tre) assigns code words to the left word and the sequences of the right words in the biword by using two independent methods. In contrast, the right text is encoded by using the left text as context. To do this, Tre uses three dictionaries: one, two, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, one, two, etc. The translation dictionary letter letter B etc. For each single word, the sequences of the independent B-letters are sorted by frequency and integral letter range.

sections.heading: 3.3 The 2LCAB Compressor
sections.text: Unlike Tre, the 2-level Compressor for Aligned Bittexts (2lcab; Adiego et al., 2009) encodes each biword with a single codeword based on a two-level dictionary; the first level consists of two dictionaries, L and R, which contain the left words or the sequences of the right words that occur in the biword sequence B. The second level dictionary B stores the different biwords in B as an integer sequence of alternating references to the entries in L and R. The text in sequence B can then refer to a sequence of references to entries in B. The header line contains L and R, which are compressed, as in Tre, using a PPM algorithm (Cleary & Witten, 1984); it also contains the codewords (selected using the Huffman compression method) for the integrators in the sequence that describe the dictionary B, with a PPM algorithm (Witten, 1984).

sections.heading: 6. Translation Spotting with Compressed Bitexts
sections.text: The exploitation of bittexts by computer-aided translation tools has evolved from simple bilingual concordants (Barlow, 2004; Bowker & Barlow, 2004) to advanced translation search engines (Callison-Burch, Bannard, & Schroeder, 2005a; Bourdaillet, Huet, Langlais, & Lapalme, 2010).The default translation units processed by bilingual concordants are sentences, and these concordants can therefore only deliver a full sentence as a result of a translation search.In contrast, translation search engines have translation capabilities, i.e. they can retrieve parallel text segments in bitexes.It seems as if existing translation search engines (Callison-Burch et al, 2005a; Bourdaillet et al, 2010) the translation search engines have their translation capabilities, i.e. they can retrieve the sequences in bitexes.

sections.heading: 6.1 Searchable 2LCAB Compression
sections.text: There are several alternative compression methods, such as ETDC, that allow direct searches in compressed text. In contrast to the output of Huffman compression, the ETDC header only stores words, since each codeword can be derived from the word position - henceforth, the words are sorted according to their relative frequency in the document to be compressed. This means that there is always an image that can be derived from the word position that the ETDC codeword returns for the nth most common word, along with the corresponding inverted bits. For example, if the B-th byte in the compressed bilingual dictionary contains an image that contains a letterword code whose rank must be searched for in B.9. Of course, this ranking can be achieved by keeping the number of words n in the list, but the standard pattern matching algorithms - such as BM (yer Moore, 1977) or Katt Morris - are not suitable.

sections.heading: 6.2 Translation Spotting
sections.text: The 2lcab searchable algorithm described above is supplemented by a search algorithm that, when a single word w is included in the left-hand text, proceeds as follows: 1. The word w is searched for in the ECL - the relatively small size of which allows an uncompressed copy to be stored in memory - and its identifier n, given by the word position in the ECL, is used to obtain its ETDC codeword c = code (n). 2. An exact pattern matching algorithm (Knuth et al., 1977) identifies all occurrences of the codeword c in the ECL biword dictionary.

In the words of Melamed (2001, p. 1), “bitexts are one of the richest sources of linguistic knowledge because the translation of a text into another language can be viewed as a detailed annotation of what that text means”. Bitexts are usually available in a compressed form in order to reduce storage requirements, to improve access times (Ziviani, Moura, Navarro, & Baeza-Yates, 2000), and to increase the efficiency of transmissions. However, the independent compression of the two texts of a bitext is clearly far from efficient because the information contained in both texts is redundant: in theory, one of the texts might be sufficient to generate a translated version if reliable machine translation systems were already available (Nevill-Manning & Bell, 1992). The improvement in compression performance obtained when taking advantage of the fact that the two texts in a bitext are mutual translations may be regarded as an indication of the quality of word alignments (Och & Ney, 2003). This indicator, which bounds the mutual information (Cover & Thomas, 1991) in the two texts of a bitext, does not require a manually-annotated corpus to evaluate the automatic alignment. The first article dealing with the compression of bitexts was published by Nevill-Manning and Bell (1992). This approach compressed one of the texts in isolation, while the other was compressed by a general prediction by partial matching (PPM; Cleary & Witten, 1984) encoder based on a model that used the automatic translation of the left text to predict the words in the right text.

metadata.abstractText: Large bilingual parallel texts (also known as bitexts) are usually stored in a compressed form, and previous work has shown that they can be more efficiently compressed if the fact that the two texts are mutual translations is exploited. For example, a bitext can be seen as a sequence of biwords —pairs of parallel words with a high probability of cooccurrence— that can be used as an intermediate representation in the compression process. However, the simple biword approach described in the literature can only exploit one-toone word alignments and cannot tackle the reordering of words. We therefore introduce a generalization of biwords which can describe multi-word expressions and reorderings. We also describe some methods for the binary compression of generalized biword sequences, and compare their performance when different schemes are applied to the extraction of the biword sequence. In addition, we show that this generalization of biwords allows for the implementation of an efficient algorithm to look on the compressed bitext for words or text segments in one of the texts and retrieve their counterpart translations in the other text —an application usually referred to as translation spotting— with only some minor modifications in the compression algorithm.
